elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Two metal–organic frameworks, namely, [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BIMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2.5</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(1,3-dpp)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd = 2,2′-(naphthalene-1,5-diylbis(oxy))diacetic acid, BIMB = 1,4-<ce:italic>bis</ce:italic>[(1H-imidazol-1-ly)methyl]benzene, 1,3-dpp = 1,3-di(pyridin-4-yl)propane) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a two-dimensional network with point symbol of (3<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>hxl</ce:bold> topology. Moreover, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays a novel 2-fold interpenetrated structure with the point symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> topology based on the hexanuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>(N)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] unit as a six-connected node. Meanwhile, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows good fluorescence property in the solid state at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two metal-organic frameworks, namely, [Ni2(BIMB)2(ndd)2⋅H2O] n  (1) and [Zn3(ndd)2.5(μ 3-OH)(1,3-dpp)] n  (2) (H2ndd = 2,2'-(naphthalene-1,5-diylbis(oxy))diacetic acid, BIMB = 1,4-bis[(1H-imidazol-1-ly)methyl]benzene, 1,3-dpp = 1,3-di(pyridin-4-yl)propane) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis. Compound 1 presents a two-dimensional network with point symbol of (36⋅46⋅53)-hxl topology. Moreover, compound 2 displays a novel 2-fold interpenetrated structure with the point symbol of (412⋅63)-pcu topology based on the hexanuclear [Zn6(CO2)10(N)4] unit as a six-connected node. Meanwhile, compound 2 shows good fluorescence property in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

      

Highlights

   ⋅ Compound 1 presents a two-dimensional layers structure with point symbol of (36⋅46⋅53)-hxl topology.   ⋅ Compound 2 exhibits the 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure.   ⋅ Compound 2 shows the point symbol of the (34⋅47⋅54)-pcu topology based on the hexanuclear zinc clusters as the six-connected node.   ⋅ Compound 2 shows fluorescence property in the solid state at room temperature.

<ce:figure id="undfig1">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a two-dimensional layers structure with point symbol of (3<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>hxl</ce:bold> topology.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits the 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the point symbol of the (3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> topology based on the hexanuclear zinc clusters as the six-connected node.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020a" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows fluorescence property in the solid state at room temperature.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0030">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The current interest in metal–organic frameworks not only stems from their potential applications in microelectronics, nonlinear optics, porous materials, and catalysis, but also from their intriguing variety of topologies and entanglement motifs . In recent years, a number of metal–organic frameworks with various structural types and topological features has been documented . Generally, the topological architectures of the metal–organic frameworks can be controlled by the deliberate design and judicious choice of the organic ligands and coordination geometries of the metal ions. In this aspect, the structural features of the organic ligands, such as shape, functionality, flexibility, symmetry, length, and substituent group, can influence the final structure types of the coordination polymers directly . Among the reported structures, organic ligands with carboxylate groups are particularly interesting because of their various coordination modes to metal ions . Thus, we have designed a multi-carboxylate ligand, 2,2′-(naphthalene-1,5-diylbis(oxy))diacetic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>), possessing flexibility owing to the presence of –O–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>– group between the phenyl ring and carboxyl moiety, to construct novel coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Compound 1 presents a two-dimensional layers structure with point symbol of (36⋅46⋅53)-hxl topology.

Compound 2 exhibits the 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure.

Compound 2 shows the point symbol of the (34⋅47⋅54)-pcu topology based on the hexanuclear zinc clusters as the six-connected node.

Compound 2 shows fluorescence property in the solid state at room temperature.

Introduction

The current interest in metal-organic frameworks not only stems from their potential applications in microelectronics, nonlinear optics, porous materials, and catalysis, but also from their intriguing variety of topologies and entanglement motifs . In recent years, a number of metal-organic frameworks with various structural types and topological features has been documented . Generally, the topological architectures of the metal-organic frameworks can be controlled by the deliberate design and judicious choice of the organic ligands and coordination geometries of the metal ions. In this aspect, the structural features of the organic ligands, such as shape, functionality, flexibility, symmetry, length, and substituent group, can influence the final structure types of the coordination polymers directly . Among the reported structures, organic ligands with carboxylate groups are particularly interesting because of their various coordination modes to metal ions . Thus, we have designed a multi-carboxylate ligand, 2,2'-(naphthalene-1,5-diylbis(oxy))diacetic acid (H2ndd,  ), possessing flexibility owing to the presence of -O-CH2- group between the phenyl ring and carboxyl moiety, to construct novel coordination polymers.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">On the other hand, many research have been concerned with the synthesis of metal–organic frameworks by incorporating a second organic ligand such as 2,2′-bipyridine, 4,4′-bipyridine or 1,10-phenanthroline into the structures of coordination polymers . As a continuation of our search for new coordination network, a fairly effective way to construct desirable networks is the introduction of the flexible N-donor ligands, such as 1,4-<ce:italic>bis</ce:italic>((1H-imidazol-1-ly)methyl)benzene, 1,3-di(pyridin-4-yl)propane. Herein, two new complexes, [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BIMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2.5</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(1,3-dpp)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), have been synthesized from the reactions of the Ni(II) or Zn(II) with 2,2′-(naphthalene-1,5-diylbis(oxy))diacetic acid in the presence of flexible N-donor auxiliary ligands. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows 2D grid with the (3<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>hxl</ce:bold> topology based on the binuclear cluster as a six-connected node. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits the 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure with point symbol of the (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> topology.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, many research have been concerned with the synthesis of metal-organic frameworks by incorporating a second organic ligand such as 2,2'-bipyridine, 4,4'-bipyridine or 1,10-phenanthroline into the structures of coordination polymers . As a continuation of our search for new coordination network, a fairly effective way to construct desirable networks is the introduction of the flexible N-donor ligands, such as 1,4-bis((1H-imidazol-1-ly)methyl)benzene, 1,3-di(pyridin-4-yl)propane. Herein, two new complexes, [Ni2(BIMB)2(ndd)2⋅H2O] n  (1), [Zn3(ndd)2.5(μ 3-OH)(1,3-dpp)] n  (2), have been synthesized from the reactions of the Ni(II) or Zn(II) with 2,2'-(naphthalene-1,5-diylbis(oxy))diacetic acid in the presence of flexible N-donor auxiliary ligands. Compound 1 shows 2D grid with the (36⋅46⋅53)-hxl topology based on the binuclear cluster as a six-connected node. Compound 2 exhibits the 2-fold interpenetrating 3D structure with point symbol of the (412⋅63)-pcu topology.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0035">Experimental sections</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0040">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The ligand of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd, BIMB and 1,3-dpp was synthesized readily by the procedure reported in the literature . Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were performed with a Perkin–Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> on a Mattson Alpha–Centauri spectrometer (). Solid-state luminescent spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse spectrophotometer (Varian) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed with a Perkin–Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 40 to 1000 °C under nitrogen.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental sections

Materials and methods

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The ligand of H2ndd, BIMB and 1,3-dpp was synthesized readily by the procedure reported in the literature . Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer (). Solid-state luminescent spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse spectrophotometer (Varian) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed with a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 40 to 1000 °C under nitrogen.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">Synthesis of complex</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">Synthesis of [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BIMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (1)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">A mixture of Ni(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.058 g, 0.2 mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd (0.055 g, 0.2 mmol) BIMB (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol) in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 150 °C for 3 days and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Yellow green crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 42.6% (based on Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salts). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">56</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1160.43): C, 57.96; H, 4.34; N, 9.66%. Found: C, 56.85; H, 4.01; N, 9.32% IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3420.43(m), 3031.44(m), 2970.20(m), 2899.39(m), 2315.93(s), 1641.13(w), 1509.98(w), 1401.63(w), 1357.18(m), 1321.58(w), 1271.27(w), 1174.85(w), 1097.31(w), 938.12(m), 879.58(m), 791.30(m), 714.95(w), 683.18(m), 630.81(w), 537.70(s).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complex

Synthesis of [Ni2(BIMB)2(ndd)2⋅H2O] n  (1)

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.058 g, 0.2 mmol), H2ndd (0.055 g, 0.2 mmol) BIMB (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 150 °C for 3 days and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Yellow green crystals of 1 were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 42.6% (based on NiII salts). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C56H50N8O13Ni2 (1160.43): C, 57.96; H, 4.34; N, 9.66%. Found: C, 56.85; H, 4.01; N, 9.32% IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3420.43(m), 3031.44(m), 2970.20(m), 2899.39(m), 2315.93(s), 1641.13(w), 1509.98(w), 1401.63(w), 1357.18(m), 1321.58(w), 1271.27(w), 1174.85(w), 1097.31(w), 938.12(m), 879.58(m), 791.30(m), 714.95(w), 683.18(m), 630.81(w), 537.70(s).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">Synthesis of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2.5</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(1,3-dpp)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (2)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">A mixture of Zn(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd (0.055 g, 0.2 mmol), 1,3-dpp (0.040 g 0.2 mmol) in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 150 °C for 3 days and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Yellow crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 43.2% (based on Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salts). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">48</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (1097.06): C, 52.55; H, 3.68; N, 2.55%. Found: C, 52.05; H, 3.41; N, 2.14%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3666.21(m), 3415.79(m), 3062.10(m), 2908(m), 1951.29(m), 1600(w), 1549.16(w), 1508.59(w), 1410.49(w), 1302.56(w), 1252.58(w), 1168.47(w), 1141.60(w), 1066.16(w), 857.46(w), 784.20(w), 699.27(w), 507.35(w), 473.07(w).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Zn3(ndd)2.5(μ 3-OH)(1,3-dpp)] n  (2)

A mixture of Zn(Ac)2⋅2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), H2ndd (0.055 g, 0.2 mmol), 1,3-dpp (0.040 g 0.2 mmol) in H2O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 150 °C for 3 days and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Yellow crystals of 2 were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 43.2% (based on ZnII salts). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C48H40N2O16Zn3 (1097.06): C, 52.55; H, 3.68; N, 2.55%. Found: C, 52.05; H, 3.41; N, 2.14%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3666.21(m), 3415.79(m), 3062.10(m), 2908(m), 1951.29(m), 1600(w), 1549.16(w), 1508.59(w), 1410.49(w), 1302.56(w), 1252.58(w), 1168.47(w), 1141.60(w), 1066.16(w), 857.46(w), 784.20(w), 699.27(w), 507.35(w), 473.07(w).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0060">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Data collection of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was performed on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the SADABS program. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXTL-97) with atomic coordinates and anisotropic thermal parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms . The hydrogen atoms of aromatic rings were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model. In compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, H atoms of water molecules could not be introduced in the refinement but were included in the structure factor calculation. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Data collection of compounds 1 and 2 was performed on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the SADABS program. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXTL-97) with atomic coordinates and anisotropic thermal parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms . The hydrogen atoms of aromatic rings were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model. In compound 2, H atoms of water molecules could not be introduced in the refinement but were included in the structure factor calculation. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0065">Results and discussions</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0070">Syntheses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were successfully synthesized by reacting Ni(II) or Zn(II) salts, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd ligand and different secondary N-containing ligands at 150 °C for 3 days under hydrothermal conditions. When the semi-rigid BIMB was introduced into the reaction system, the two-dimensional compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained. When the flexible 1,3-dpp bridging ligand was adopted, one three-dimensional compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was produced. The infrared spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were consistent with their formulations. Features corresponding to the skeletal vibrations of aromatic rings and heterocyclic rings for these complexes were observed in the range of 1321–1440 cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 1302–1410 cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The absorption bands 1509 and 1641 cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 1508 and 1600 cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in the IR spectra are attributed to the characteristic asymmetric stretching vibration of coordinated carboxylic groups due to the formation of Ni(II)–O and Zn(II)–O coordination bonds of carboxylic oxygen atom in the ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussions

Syntheses

Complexes 1-2 were successfully synthesized by reacting Ni(II) or Zn(II) salts, H2ndd ligand and different secondary N-containing ligands at 150 °C for 3 days under hydrothermal conditions. When the semi-rigid BIMB was introduced into the reaction system, the two-dimensional compound 1 was obtained. When the flexible 1,3-dpp bridging ligand was adopted, one three-dimensional compound 2 was produced. The infrared spectra of 1 and 2 were consistent with their formulations. Features corresponding to the skeletal vibrations of aromatic rings and heterocyclic rings for these complexes were observed in the range of 1321-1440 cm-1 for 1 and 1302-1410 cm-1 for 2. The absorption bands 1509 and 1641 cm-1 in 1, 1508 and 1600 cm-1 in 2 in the IR spectra are attributed to the characteristic asymmetric stretching vibration of coordinated carboxylic groups due to the formation of Ni(II)-O and Zn(II)-O coordination bonds of carboxylic oxygen atom in the ligand.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0075">Description of structures</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">[Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BIMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> and the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains two Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions, two BIMB ligands, two ndd ligands and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a six-connected 2D network which is built from the dinuclear Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit. Meanwhile, each Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion in the dinuclear motif is coordinated by three carboxylic oxygen atoms of three ndd ligands (Ni–O 2.039(3)–2.094(3) Å), one oxygen atom of a water molecule (Ni–O 2.108(3) Å) and two nitrogen atoms of two BIMB ligands (Ni<ce:bold>–</ce:bold>N 2.074(4)<ce:bold>–</ce:bold>2.094(3) Å) to furnish a distorted octahedral geometry () . Two symmetry-related Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers are bridged by two bidentate carboxylate groups from two ndd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions and one bridging H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule to furnish [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] fragment in which the Ni⋯Ni distance is 3.566(17) Å (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a). The axis sites of each Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are occupied by four additional BIMB ligands via nitrogen atom. Although each metal cluster is ligated by eight bridging ligands, it is virtually linked to six nearest-neighbors (six {Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} cluster) with distances of 13.611(25)–15.905(5) Å (center–center) (b). The extension of this structure results in a 2D layer structure (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of structures

[Ni2(BIMB)2(ndd)2⋅H2O] (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and the structure of 1 contains two NiII ions, two BIMB ligands, two ndd ligands and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. Compound 1 shows a six-connected 2D network which is built from the dinuclear Ni2 unit. Meanwhile, each NiII ion in the dinuclear motif is coordinated by three carboxylic oxygen atoms of three ndd ligands (Ni-O 2.039(3)-2.094(3) Å), one oxygen atom of a water molecule (Ni-O 2.108(3) Å) and two nitrogen atoms of two BIMB ligands (Ni-N 2.074(4)-2.094(3) Å) to furnish a distorted octahedral geometry () . Two symmetry-related NiII centers are bridged by two bidentate carboxylate groups from two ndd2- anions and one bridging H2O molecule to furnish [Ni2(CO2)4N2] fragment in which the Ni⋯Ni distance is 3.566(17) Å ( a). The axis sites of each Ni2 are occupied by four additional BIMB ligands via nitrogen atom. Although each metal cluster is ligated by eight bridging ligands, it is virtually linked to six nearest-neighbors (six {Ni2} cluster) with distances of 13.611(25)-15.905(5) Å (center-center) (b). The extension of this structure results in a 2D layer structure (c).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0065" view="all">From the topological point of view, the dinuclear Ni <ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> cluster is treated as a single node, each node can be considered as a six-connected node, because the two BIMB ligands form two “double-bridges”. The ndd and BIMB ligands can be seen as a linear linker between two nodes. Thus, the whole structure can be represented to a 2D network with point symbol of the (3<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>hxl</ce:bold> topology (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From the topological point of view, the dinuclear Ni II cluster is treated as a single node, each node can be considered as a six-connected node, because the two BIMB ligands form two "double-bridges". The ndd and BIMB ligands can be seen as a linear linker between two nodes. Thus, the whole structure can be represented to a 2D network with point symbol of the (36⋅46⋅53)-hxl topology (d).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In addition, there are the hydrogen-bonding interactions between the coordinated water molecules and carboxylic oxygen atoms (O1W–H⋯O13A, 2.649 Å; O1W–H⋯O8A, 2.601 Å, A, –1 + <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) in the identical 2D layers. Meanwhile, there are also strong interactions between imidazole ring from one network and imidazole ring from the other in the adjacent 2D layers (Parallel stacking with distances face–face of 3.2067(17) Å, centroid–centroid of 3.576(2) Å) which extend the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular structure. Both the hydrogen bonds and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> interactions make the whole structure stable. The hydrogen-bonding data are summarized in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In addition, there are the hydrogen-bonding interactions between the coordinated water molecules and carboxylic oxygen atoms (O1W-H⋯O13A, 2.649 Å; O1W-H⋯O8A, 2.601 Å, A, -1 + x, y, z) in the identical 2D layers. Meanwhile, there are also strong interactions between imidazole ring from one network and imidazole ring from the other in the adjacent 2D layers (Parallel stacking with distances face-face of 3.2067(17) Å, centroid-centroid of 3.576(2) Å) which extend the 2D layers into a 3D supramolecular structure. Both the hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions make the whole structure stable. The hydrogen-bonding data are summarized in .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2.5</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(1,3-dpp)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (2)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">When 1,3-dpp, a flexible N-containing ligand, is used instead of flexible ligand BIMB, a new six-connected 3D network with the <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> topology is produced. In the asymmetric unit, there are three Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions, two and half ndd ligands, one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH group and one 1,3-dpp ligand. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains a hexanuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>(N)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] clusters with non-bonding Zn⋯Zn distances of 3.360–3.418 Å. In the hexanuclear clusters, there are three crystallographically independent Zn atoms, Zn(1)–Zn(3), in which each <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH interlinks three crystallographically unique Zn atoms. Zn(1) atom coordinates to one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH moiety (Zn–O 2.048(2) Å), three carboxylate oxygen atoms (Zn–O 2.024(2)–2.103(3) Å) from three different ndd ligands and one nitrogen atom (Zn–N 2.072(3) Å) from one 1,3-dpp ligand giving a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry. The Zn(2) atom is coordinated by one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH atom (Zn–O 1.951(2) Å) and three carboxylate oxygen atoms (Zn–O 1.917(3)–2.032(3)) Å) from three ndd ligands to complete a distorted tetrahedral environment, whereas Zn(3)A exists in an approximately octahedral geometry, being ligated by one nitrogen atom (Zn–N 2.110(3) Å) from a 1,3-dpp ligand, one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH atom (Zn–O 2.053(2) Å), and four carboxylate oxygen atoms (Zn–O 2.032(3)–2.281(3) Å) from two ndd ligands, as depicted in 
. While, each hexanuclear metal cluster of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is surrounded by 14 organic ligands—10 bridging ndd ligands and four bridging 1,3-dpp ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a). Although each hexanuclear metal cluster is ligated by 14 bridging ligands, it is virtually linked to six nearest neighbors, with distances of 15.226(6)–19.065(52) Å (center–center), because two pairs of ndd ligands form two “double-bridges” (b). This, therefore, defines a six-connected node. From the topological point of view, the 3D network is considered as a six-connected net based on hexanuclear zinc clusters with point symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> topology (c) . The overall topology of the 3D frame is best described as a compressed <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>-Po net based on two intersecting (4,4) nets that possesses large distorted cube-like cavities of approximately 15.226(3) × 16.444(17) × 19.065(21) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (). The large voids are formed by the single 3D network allowing incorporation of the other identical networks, thus giving a 2-fold interpenetrated <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>-Po-related network that belongs to Class Ia (all the interpenetrated nets are generated only by translation and the translating vector is [1 0 0] (12.52 Å) as shown in d. According to the literature, the 3D networks with the hexanuclear zinc cluster are often encountered , but we are not aware of any metal–organic frameworks possessing 2-fold interpenetrating net with the point symbol (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> like what was found in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
[Zn3(ndd)2.5(μ 3-OH)(1,3-dpp)] n  (2)

When 1,3-dpp, a flexible N-containing ligand, is used instead of flexible ligand BIMB, a new six-connected 3D network with the pcu topology is produced. In the asymmetric unit, there are three ZnII ions, two and half ndd ligands, one μ 3-OH group and one 1,3-dpp ligand. Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that the structure of 2 contains a hexanuclear [Zn6(CO2)10(N)4] clusters with non-bonding Zn⋯Zn distances of 3.360-3.418 Å. In the hexanuclear clusters, there are three crystallographically independent Zn atoms, Zn(1)-Zn(3), in which each μ 3-OH interlinks three crystallographically unique Zn atoms. Zn(1) atom coordinates to one μ 3-OH moiety (Zn-O 2.048(2) Å), three carboxylate oxygen atoms (Zn-O 2.024(2)-2.103(3) Å) from three different ndd ligands and one nitrogen atom (Zn-N 2.072(3) Å) from one 1,3-dpp ligand giving a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry. The Zn(2) atom is coordinated by one μ 3-OH atom (Zn-O 1.951(2) Å) and three carboxylate oxygen atoms (Zn-O 1.917(3)-2.032(3)) Å) from three ndd ligands to complete a distorted tetrahedral environment, whereas Zn(3)A exists in an approximately octahedral geometry, being ligated by one nitrogen atom (Zn-N 2.110(3) Å) from a 1,3-dpp ligand, one μ 3-OH atom (Zn-O 2.053(2) Å), and four carboxylate oxygen atoms (Zn-O 2.032(3)-2.281(3) Å) from two ndd ligands, as depicted in  . While, each hexanuclear metal cluster of 2 is surrounded by 14 organic ligands-10 bridging ndd ligands and four bridging 1,3-dpp ligands ( a). Although each hexanuclear metal cluster is ligated by 14 bridging ligands, it is virtually linked to six nearest neighbors, with distances of 15.226(6)-19.065(52) Å (center-center), because two pairs of ndd ligands form two "double-bridges" (b). This, therefore, defines a six-connected node. From the topological point of view, the 3D network is considered as a six-connected net based on hexanuclear zinc clusters with point symbol of (412⋅63)-pcu topology (c) . The overall topology of the 3D frame is best described as a compressed α-Po net based on two intersecting (4,4) nets that possesses large distorted cube-like cavities of approximately 15.226(3) × 16.444(17) × 19.065(21) Å3 (). The large voids are formed by the single 3D network allowing incorporation of the other identical networks, thus giving a 2-fold interpenetrated α-Po-related network that belongs to Class Ia (all the interpenetrated nets are generated only by translation and the translating vector is [1 0 0] (12.52 Å) as shown in d. According to the literature, the 3D networks with the hexanuclear zinc cluster are often encountered , but we are not aware of any metal-organic frameworks possessing 2-fold interpenetrating net with the point symbol (412⋅63)-pcu like what was found in 2.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0090">Luminescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Taking into account of the excellent luminescent properties of Zn(II), the solid-state luminescent spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has been studied at room temperature. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the emission maxima at 420 nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 320 nm). In order to understand the nature of the emission, we analyzed the photoluminescent property of free organic ligand and found that the strongest emission peak of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd is at 474 nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 363 nm). It can be seen that the maximum emission peak of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays remarkable blue-shift, which can be assigned to <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>∗ → <ce:italic>n</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>∗ → <ce:italic>π</ce:italic> transitions of the ligand-to-metal (LMCT) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

Taking into account of the excellent luminescent properties of Zn(II), the solid-state luminescent spectrum of 2 has been studied at room temperature. As shown in  , compound 2 shows the emission maxima at 420 nm (λ ex = 320 nm). In order to understand the nature of the emission, we analyzed the photoluminescent property of free organic ligand and found that the strongest emission peak of H2ndd is at 474 nm (λ ex = 363 nm). It can be seen that the maximum emission peak of compound 2 displays remarkable blue-shift, which can be assigned to π∗ → n and π∗ → π transitions of the ligand-to-metal (LMCT) .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0095">Thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">To study the thermal stability of the complexes, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on polycrystalline samples under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (). The TG curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows that the framework collapsed in the temperature range of 311–567 °C, corresponding to the release of organic components. The remaining weight of 13.97% corresponds to the percentage (calcd. 12.93%) of Ni and O components, indicating that the final product may be NiO. The TG curve of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows one main weight loss. No weight losses were observed for the complex up to 342 °C; above 342 °C, significant weight losses occurred and ended at 675 °C, indicating the removal of the corresponding organic components. The remaining weight may correspond to the final product of ZnO (obsd. 18.87%, calcd. 22.15%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal properties

To study the thermal stability of the complexes, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on polycrystalline samples under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (). The TG curve of 1 shows that the framework collapsed in the temperature range of 311-567 °C, corresponding to the release of organic components. The remaining weight of 13.97% corresponds to the percentage (calcd. 12.93%) of Ni and O components, indicating that the final product may be NiO. The TG curve of 2 shows one main weight loss. No weight losses were observed for the complex up to 342 °C; above 342 °C, significant weight losses occurred and ended at 675 °C, indicating the removal of the corresponding organic components. The remaining weight may correspond to the final product of ZnO (obsd. 18.87%, calcd. 22.15%).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0100">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized two coordination polymers with different types of metal ions. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a two-dimensional structure with point symbol of (3<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·5<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>hxl</ce:bold> topology. While, the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a case of the 2-fold interpenetrating network with point symbol (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)-<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> topology based on the hexanuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] unit as a six-connected node . From the structural difference of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, it reveals that the selection of suitable organic ligands and metal ions is a major strategy to synthesize novel structure with useful properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized two coordination polymers with different types of metal ions. Compound 1 exhibits a two-dimensional structure with point symbol of (36⋅46⋅53)-hxl topology. While, the structure of 2 shows a case of the 2-fold interpenetrating network with point symbol (412⋅63)-pcu topology based on the hexanuclear [Zn6(CO2)10N4] unit as a six-connected node . From the structural difference of 1 and 2, it reveals that the selection of suitable organic ligands and metal ions is a major strategy to synthesize novel structure with useful properties.

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">Synthesis of complex</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">Synthesis of [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BIMB)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (1)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">A mixture of Ni(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.058 g, 0.2 mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd (0.055 g, 0.2 mmol) BIMB (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol) in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 150 °C for 3 days and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Yellow green crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 42.6% (based on Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salts). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">56</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1160.43): C, 57.96; H, 4.34; N, 9.66%. Found: C, 56.85; H, 4.01; N, 9.32% IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3420.43(m), 3031.44(m), 2970.20(m), 2899.39(m), 2315.93(s), 1641.13(w), 1509.98(w), 1401.63(w), 1357.18(m), 1321.58(w), 1271.27(w), 1174.85(w), 1097.31(w), 938.12(m), 879.58(m), 791.30(m), 714.95(w), 683.18(m), 630.81(w), 537.70(s).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">Synthesis of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(ndd)<ce:inf loc="post">2.5</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(1,3-dpp)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (2)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">A mixture of Zn(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd (0.055 g, 0.2 mmol), 1,3-dpp (0.040 g 0.2 mmol) in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 150 °C for 3 days and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Yellow crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 43.2% (based on Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salts). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">48</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (1097.06): C, 52.55; H, 3.68; N, 2.55%. Found: C, 52.05; H, 3.41; N, 2.14%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3666.21(m), 3415.79(m), 3062.10(m), 2908(m), 1951.29(m), 1600(w), 1549.16(w), 1508.59(w), 1410.49(w), 1302.56(w), 1252.58(w), 1168.47(w), 1141.60(w), 1066.16(w), 857.46(w), 784.20(w), 699.27(w), 507.35(w), 473.07(w).</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complex

Synthesis of [Ni2(BIMB)2(ndd)2⋅H2O] n  (1)

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.058 g, 0.2 mmol), H2ndd (0.055 g, 0.2 mmol) BIMB (0.048 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 150 °C for 3 days and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Yellow green crystals of 1 were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 42.6% (based on NiII salts). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C56H50N8O13Ni2 (1160.43): C, 57.96; H, 4.34; N, 9.66%. Found: C, 56.85; H, 4.01; N, 9.32% IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3420.43(m), 3031.44(m), 2970.20(m), 2899.39(m), 2315.93(s), 1641.13(w), 1509.98(w), 1401.63(w), 1357.18(m), 1321.58(w), 1271.27(w), 1174.85(w), 1097.31(w), 938.12(m), 879.58(m), 791.30(m), 714.95(w), 683.18(m), 630.81(w), 537.70(s).

Synthesis of [Zn3(ndd)2.5(μ 3-OH)(1,3-dpp)] n  (2)

A mixture of Zn(Ac)2⋅2H2O (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), H2ndd (0.055 g, 0.2 mmol), 1,3-dpp (0.040 g 0.2 mmol) in H2O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 150 °C for 3 days and then cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Yellow crystals of 2 were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 43.2% (based on ZnII salts). Elemental analyses calcd (%) for C48H40N2O16Zn3 (1097.06): C, 52.55; H, 3.68; N, 2.55%. Found: C, 52.05; H, 3.41; N, 2.14%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3666.21(m), 3415.79(m), 3062.10(m), 2908(m), 1951.29(m), 1600(w), 1549.16(w), 1508.59(w), 1410.49(w), 1302.56(w), 1252.58(w), 1168.47(w), 1141.60(w), 1066.16(w), 857.46(w), 784.20(w), 699.27(w), 507.35(w), 473.07(w).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0090">Luminescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Taking into account of the excellent luminescent properties of Zn(II), the solid-state luminescent spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has been studied at room temperature. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the emission maxima at 420 nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 320 nm). In order to understand the nature of the emission, we analyzed the photoluminescent property of free organic ligand and found that the strongest emission peak of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndd is at 474 nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 363 nm). It can be seen that the maximum emission peak of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays remarkable blue-shift, which can be assigned to <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>∗ → <ce:italic>n</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>∗ → <ce:italic>π</ce:italic> transitions of the ligand-to-metal (LMCT) .</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0095">Thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">To study the thermal stability of the complexes, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on polycrystalline samples under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (). The TG curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows that the framework collapsed in the temperature range of 311–567 °C, corresponding to the release of organic components. The remaining weight of 13.97% corresponds to the percentage (calcd. 12.93%) of Ni and O components, indicating that the final product may be NiO. The TG curve of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows one main weight loss. No weight losses were observed for the complex up to 342 °C; above 342 °C, significant weight losses occurred and ended at 675 °C, indicating the removal of the corresponding organic components. The remaining weight may correspond to the final product of ZnO (obsd. 18.87%, calcd. 22.15%).</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

Taking into account of the excellent luminescent properties of Zn(II), the solid-state luminescent spectrum of 2 has been studied at room temperature. As shown in  , compound 2 shows the emission maxima at 420 nm (λ ex = 320 nm). In order to understand the nature of the emission, we analyzed the photoluminescent property of free organic ligand and found that the strongest emission peak of H2ndd is at 474 nm (λ ex = 363 nm). It can be seen that the maximum emission peak of compound 2 displays remarkable blue-shift, which can be assigned to π∗ → n and π∗ → π transitions of the ligand-to-metal (LMCT) .

Thermal properties

To study the thermal stability of the complexes, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on polycrystalline samples under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (). The TG curve of 1 shows that the framework collapsed in the temperature range of 311-567 °C, corresponding to the release of organic components. The remaining weight of 13.97% corresponds to the percentage (calcd. 12.93%) of Ni and O components, indicating that the final product may be NiO. The TG curve of 2 shows one main weight loss. No weight losses were observed for the complex up to 342 °C; above 342 °C, significant weight losses occurred and ended at 675 °C, indicating the removal of the corresponding organic components. The remaining weight may correspond to the final product of ZnO (obsd. 18.87%, calcd. 22.15%).

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

metadata.title: Hydrothermal synthesis and structure characterization of two six-connected metal–organic frameworks based on the mixed ligands
